ai-ud3.1:0.2_0: 3.1. Born of the Fruits of deeds
ai-ud3.1:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-ud3.1:1.3_0: Now, at that time a certain mendicant was sitting not far from the Buddha cross-legged, with his body straight. As a result of past deeds, he suffered painful, sharp, severe, and acute feelings, which he endured unperturbed, with mindfulness and awareness.
ai-ud3.1:2.1_0: The Buddha saw him meditating and enduring that pain.
ai-ud3.1:3.1_0: Knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ai-ud3.1:4.1_0: “A mendicant who has left all deeds behind,
ai-ud3.1:4.2_0: shaking off the dust of past deeds,
ai-ud3.1:4.5_0: First the first part of the body.
